column41: NOTES: After playback, bird was initially silent, but eventually it began singing again much closer to us; glimpsed by JFP; song was the same, but intersong interval was much shorter after playback; apparently 6-8 meters away and two meters up in very dense growth

column16: Trilha de Tres Picos above Hotel Simon
column43: NOTES: Same bird as cuts #97-07-19, 20 recorded previous day; after playback of tape recorded previous day (probably #97-07-20); response was same as previously, a silent approach followed eventually by the same song given with a shorter intersong interval; unseen but apparently 10-12 meters away and 1-2 meters up in desne undergrowth, much of it bamboo; weather same, but temperature about 54¡.

column41: NOTES: Neotropical Institute Cut # 4. Brazil (Misc.Formicariide); Bulk reel: 192. 203 tape.   Natural song. Also hear prominently the "churrs" of Todirostrum plumbiceps. Quality: 2. Level: +5. Then after playback. Quality: 1-2. Level: +5. Collected.       Belton Data: RRN: 372. How Identified: Sight and Sound. Confidence in Identification: 100%. Location: 5KM SE of Canela; Morro Pelado. Latitude: 29¡22'S. Longitude: 50¡49'W. Elevation: 850m. Vocalization: Song and Call. Environmental Zone: Subtropical. Habitat Class: Forest. Habitat Subclass: Coniferous, Deciduous, Evergreen, Undergrowth. Strata in Habitat: Surface. Number of individuals: 2 Adults sex unknown. Belton Data entered 11Nov2009 mf.  LNS:  Subject changed from Hylopezus ochroleucus to H. nattereri to reflect current taxonomy. -Matt Medler, 17 January 2011.

column42: NOTES: Neotropical Institute Cut # 6. Bulk reel: 143 a) Natural song. Very likely same bird as in Cut 5). Quality: "1". Level: +5. b) After playback. Quality: 1. Ledvel: +5. This bird was then collected, pickled whole, and sent to Geo. Lowery at LSU in Aug. 1968.

column41: NOTES: (Species Sound:  Infrequent; Cover Den: Thick;  Season: Winter;  Cassette) Bird came in, circled us calling.   It hops rapidly across the forest floor - like a thrush in appearance. column50: NOTES: Unseen bird was now at distance of 4 m and within 1 m of ground, and roughly in same spot as it was for cut #97RDAT19-09 in very dense growth right at edge of bungalow clearing.  More clouds but conditions other wise same [calm, upper 70s].  Note that I saw this bird the following day, using in part playback of this recording.  In response to tape playback, the bird would immediately go silent, then run by me at a distance of 12-15 m, and finally it began singing again from a nearby perch.  When seen, bird was singing about 1 m up on horizontal perch amid dense growth, much of it bamboo.  Bird described briefly on tape.    ML: Background subject changed from recordist's original identification of Ramphastos tucanus cuvieri to Ramphastos tucanus to conform to eBird Taxonomy (v. 1.55). -Jay McGowan/Matt Medler, July 2015.    ML: Background subject changed from recordist's original identification of Xiphorhynchus guttatus eytoni to Xiphorhynchus guttatus [eytoni Group] to conform to eBird Taxonomy (v. 1.55). -Jay McGowan/Matt Medler, July 2015.

NOTES: Unseen bird was at distance of 8 m and about 1 m up in very dense growth right at edge of bungalow clearing.  Mostly cloudy with thunderheads in the distance, calm, upper 70s.  Time announcement difficult to decipher and apparently incorrect (said to be 17:39, but following cut was recorded earlier than this!)  Probably recorded at about 17:10 based on timing of following cut.

column44:
NOTES: Unseen bird was probably 20 meters away at first, but later possibly as close as 8-10 meters away, and low in dense undergrowth of good, terra firme forest along the trail at 200 meters North between Trails J and K; presumably the same individual highlighted in cuts #2000-12-11 & 13, and #2000-13-01; this was recorded following playback of three songs from cut #2000-13-01, in response to which, the bird flew across the trail and began singing more frequently; clear, calm, 85¡F; HHb filters off.

ML: Subject changed from Hylopezus macularius to H. paraensis to reflect current taxonomy. -Jay McGowan 29Nov2014.
column45: Response to playback: Approach. Response to playback: Normal song.

column50:
NOTES: HHb filters in cut position; attenuators off on both recorder and microphone; same bird as above cut (RRN #98RDAT17-11) after playback of itself; I was now on Trail 5S (250 meters) between trails Q and R; response to playback was a slightly shorter intersong interval and minimal movement; bird appeared to be within a meter of the ground in good, terra firme forest; unseen, despite much effort.

ML: Subject changed from Hylopezus macularius to H. paraensis to reflect current taxonomy. -Jay McGowan 29Nov2014.

NOTES: Location: several km from north bank of Rio Tahuamanu; "San Sebastian has an extensive trail system - a grid cut at 100m. intervals over a 150 ha study area that extends in all directions from camp. Areas to N, W and S of camp are on well-drained terrace; areas to SE are lower and wetter. Bamboo occurs in small patches to NW and in more extensive areas just to the S of camp.
